p:
As is well known, the wettability of a surface is mainly governed by its chemical composition and roughness
21– 24 . In particular, the hierarchical microscale and nanoscale structures of the meshes play important roles. The surface roughness of the microstructures formed by acid etching and anodizing of an aluminium mesh was investigated by analysing atomic force microscope (AFM) images of its surface. Figure 1 shows representative AFM three-dimensional views of the pristine and treated aluminium meshes, as well as their topographic height profiles. It can be clearly seen that the etching and anodizing processes resulted in a significant increase in the surface roughness, commonly represented by R a, the arithmetic average of the surface roughness in nanometres. The larger the value of R a, the rougher the surface. R a of the untreated aluminium mesh was 35.3 nm, and R a of the etched and anodized aluminium mesh was 410 nm; the resulting hierarchical microstructures and nanostructures thus favoured wetting of the surface.
